column2: Write five sentences. They can be as long or as short as you like, but try to make them more than simple descriptive sentences.

column1: Read a random wikipedia page in your target language
column2: Visit https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/List_of_Wikipedias, pick the wiki in your language of study, then on the left hand side find a "random article". Read the page for 15 minutes to understand the contents. Spend the final 15 minutes writing a summary of what you learned, or tell a friend.

column1: Read any random text you have near you
column2: Read for 30 minutes in any random text you have near you or on your computer / phone. BONUS: Highlight or mark any words you don't understand.

Bliubliu is a great site for getting some quick reading practice. (If you don't already have an account, take the 30 minutes to get set up). Pick a topic and let Bliubliu give you short texts. Click the words you know so it knows what level you're at.
Write a poem. It can be about anything. Just get writing. Don't spend too much time thinking about this one. The point is to write and use your language.

Readlang is a service that allows you to read longer texts, look up words and test yourself on the new words you learnt while reading. (If you don't already have an account, take a few minutes to get set up). Pick a text (either an article you found online, or use the service's own library to suggest a text).

Research the biography of a well-known figure from the culture or history of the country/people who speak your target language. Use original-language materials. Get the outline of their life story. Start with local-language wikipedia.

column1: Write a paragraph of text (last-letter edition)
column2: Write a paragraph of text in which the last letter of the previous word determines the first letter of the next word. This is harder than it sounds. Try not to think too much, though, and keep writing.

column1: Read something written over 100 years ago
column2: Find something written in your target language that was written over 100 years ago. Notice how the language is different from the kinds of things you read online. Notice any similarities. Enjoy this mental time-travel experience!

column1: Read something written over 1000 years ago
column2: If your language is old enough, find something written in your target language that was written over 1000 years ago. Notice how the language is different from the kinds of things you read online. Notice any similarities. Enjoy this mental time-travel experience!
Find a friend studying the same language as you, someone at a similar competency level. Have a conversation with them.
Send an email to a friend who speaks your target language. Tell them what you're up to, what you've been studying, or anything else you'd like!

Read through as much of a news article as is possible in 30 minutes. Either visit BBC News' local-language edition or another website published using your target language. If you finish before the time is over, start a new article.

column1: Write a summary of an article you read recently
column2: Begin by explaining the overall gist of the article, then get into the specifics of how the piece argued its message. Try to use some of the same vocabulary or phrases that were used in the original article. Don't think too much about this; keep writing. Keep communicating.

column1: Listen to part of a podcast episode
column2: If you don't use a podcast player, maybe spend the time setting this up. Once that's done, do a search online for "[your language] podcasts" and pick a few podcasts that interest you. Subscribe to them using your podcast player, and listen to 30 minutes of an episode. Your player will keep your place in the podcast for when you next listen, so don't worry if the 30 minutes finishes before the end of the episode.

column1: Summarise the last film you saw
column2: Do this in writing or out loud. Describe the plot. Explain whether you liked the film or not. Explain why. BONUS: Record your summary/review and post it to YouTube. Or if you wrote it down, post it to Lang-8.

column1: Summarise the last book you read
column2: Do this in writing or out loud. Describe the plot. Explain whether you liked the book or not. Explain why. BONUS: Record your summary/review and post it to YouTube. Or if you wrote it down, post it to Lang-8.

Take 30 minutes to translate something you read recently. A partial translation is fine. Post your translation somewhere online with a link to the original source text when the 10 minutes are up. BONUS: Consider having a dedicated blog or tumblr where you can post your translations as you do them. This way you'll have a log of your study progress.

column1: Record a conversation with a friend
column2: Talk about anything you'd like, but don't use anything other than your target language. Once the time is up, post the conversation online to Youtube or Soundcloud. BONUS: Consider doing this more regularly and you'll have your own podcast.

column1: Write a guide to the city where you live
column2: Write a guide to the city where you live to a visitor from the country where your target language is spoken. List the best places to visit for tourism, the best places to shop and what else someone should do in town. BONUS: Post this to lang-8, and/or record the passage and post that audio recording to Soundcloud.
Write some sentences using words that you learned only recently. Post these practice sentences to Lang-8 to make sure that you're using the words in the right way / context.

Walk around the block or walk around the area where you're studying/based. As you walk, have an inner monologue in which you describe everything you see around you. Keep talking to yourself; don't use English. When you get back, make a note of the words you were unable to recall.

Search YouTube for a news report or short film about any topic that interests you. Make sure it is in your target language and that it lasts roughly 20-30 minutes. Watch the video. BONUS: Write a short summary of the contents of this film.

column1: Research a topic that interests you
column2: Use only sources in your target language. Read a variety of sources. Start to figure out the outlines of that topic.

Pick something you learnt or researched recently. Summarise the important points about that topic or issue. Summarise the main sources you used to come to these conclusions. BONUS: Post your summary to Lang-8 or your blog for feedback.

Visit iteslj.org/questions/ and pick a topic. Look at the questions. Imagine you had to answer the questions in your target language. What vocabulary would you need to know to be able to answer those questions? Make a note of these missing words. Start practicing some of the answers to the questions.
Think of something you know, but a friend doesn't know. Take thirty minutes to teach that topic or skill to your friend, using only your target language.

Think of something you know. Record a video to YouTube in which you teach that topic or skill, using only your target language. Don't think about this too much. Take a few minutes to sketch out a rough structure and then just get talking.
Write about what you did during the past 12 months. BONUS: Post it to Lang-8 or your blog for feedback and/or corrections.
Write about what you want to do during the coming 12 months. BONUS: Post it to Lang-8 or your blog for feedback and/or corrections.
Write about what you consider to be the qualities possessed by a good leader. BONUS: Post it to Lang-8 or your blog for feedback and/or corrections.
Describe earth and human society to a visiting alien. BONUS: Post it to Lang-8 or your blog for feedback and/or corrections.
Write an essay with the title "things only a local would know." BONUS: Post it to Lang-8 or your blog for feedback and/or corrections.
Describe life in the town where you live from the perspective of a dog. BONUS: Post it to Lang-8 or your blog for feedback and/or corrections.
Describe life in the town where you live from the perspective of a cat. BONUS: Post it to Lang-8 or your blog for feedback and/or corrections.
Describe life in the town where you live from the perspective of a spider. BONUS: Post it to Lang-8 or your blog for feedback and/or corrections.
Write an essay that begins, "If I were the president of my country..." BONUS: Post it to Lang-8 or your blog for feedback and/or corrections.
Write an essay that begins, "If I could travel through time..." BONUS: Post it to Lang-8 or your blog for feedback and/or corrections.
Write a story that happened to you from your childhood. BONUS: Post it to Lang-8 or your blog for feedback and/or corrections.
Write an essay about why you are studying this particular language.
Write an essay with the title "The Best Day of My Life." BONUS: Post it to Lang-8 or your blog for feedback and/or corrections.
Write an essay with the title "The Worst Day of My Life." BONUS: Post it to Lang-8 or your blog for feedback and/or corrections.

Take some time to read up on a grammar point that you know you find difficult but always put off really taking the time to understand. Try to get to the point where you understand what's going on / how it works. BONUS: Once you understand, try teaching it to someone else. This will cement your understanding.

column1: Summarise a short film or documentary
column2: Recall the contents of a short film or documentary you watched recently. Ideally you'll have watched it in your target language. Write a summary of that film or documentary, starting with the big ideas and slowly adding in the more intricate points. End by analysing the content, and/or expressing your opinion.

Write a short review in your target language. First summarise the content of the book, then state what you thought about it. Finally, explain how it fits in the context of other things you've read or heard.
Start writing a short story in your target language. Don't worry about the quality for now. Just focus on telling a story as best you can, using the full extent of your language.
You're stuck on a desert island. Write or speak out loud (ideally to someone else) a description of how you'd deal with this situation. Describe how you'd feel.

You are driving in a remote area during heavy winter and your car breaks down. You don't know which way to go to find help, but if you stay out in the cold you probably won't survive. Write or speak out loud (ideally to someone else) a description of how you'd deal with this situation. Describe how you'd feel.

Write a short post online (on Facebook, Tumblr or your blog) explaining something that you struggled to learn recently. Share the lessons of how you managed to deal with this and surmount your difficulties.

Do a search online for "[your language] volunteer translation opportunities" and you will probably find some people looking for volunteer help translating materials. Some open-source software projects will have specific tools to help you contribute.

Use an article you recently read as the basis for this exercise. Write 10-15 comprehension questions based on the content of the article in your target language. BONUS: Post them on your blog or on Facebook along with the original article for others to use.

column1: Write a guide to a grammar feature
column2: Write a short guide to a particular feature of grammar in your target language. Feel free to write it in your mother-tongue. BONUS: Post this grammar guide on your blog or even on Facebook or Tumblr.

column1: Write a letter to your past self
column2: Imagine you could write a short note to your past self, to the person you were a few years ago (or more). What would you say? Write a note to this past self.

column1: Write a letter to your future self
column2: Imagine you could write a short note to your future self, to the person you you will become in a few years (or more). What would you say? Write a note to this future self.

Foreigncy is a website with exercises and selections of media articles (and associated short video clips) on topics currently in the news. Check if their selections are available for your language. If so, take 30 minutes to do all the exercises for one of their free sets.
Pick a song in your target language. Look up the lyrics. Learn the song by heart.

Your city or the place where you live probably has some problems it needs fixing. Take this time to outline and then write a city plan (in your target language) that could be taken and used to fix the problems. Begin each paragraph by stating the specific problem you want to solve, and then end with the solution. BONUS: Post this on lang-8 (http://www.lang-8.com/) and get corrections!.

Use Clozemaster (https://www.clozemaster.com/) to practice your target language. You'll get a sentence and a translation and you'll have to choose what words fills in the blanks. Enjoy this game; it's compulsively addictive.

Contribute to the Tatoeba Project by translating some sentences from your target language into your mother tongue. Visit https://tatoeba.org/eng/activities/translate_sentences to get started. Keep going until the time is up.

Find some cartoons that use your target language. YouTube will have lots. This task is all about the fun. You've been working hard, so this is where you just get to enjoy watching cartoons for the entirety of the time period you chose. Well done!

Visit TuneIn online radio (http://tunein.com/) and search for a radio station in the country where your target language is spoken. Pick a random or a favourite station and listen to it for half the time allocated. Take notes while you're listening. Once you reach half-way, turn the radio off and try to write a summary. Alternatively, try saying it out loud (either just to yourself or to someone else).

This is an exercise to keep writing. Complete the sentence "when I was young..." however you feel appropriate. Whenever you get stuck, go back to the original prompt and try to think of something new/different that happened when you were young. BONUS: Read the text of what you wrote out loud after you've finished writing.
Write for thirty minutes about the most pressing problem you think currently faces mankind. Explain why you chose that topic and give reasons. BONUS: Post this to lang-8.com for corrections.

If you have a website of your own, take this thirty minutes to translate the main design and headings into your target language. Consider offering a parallel site that caters to users who speak that language. BONUS: Actually implement this!

Start work translating your CV into your target language. Look up (via an internet search) some examples of CVs originating in your target language so you have an idea about the style people use, and then get translating!
Write for thirty minutes about the country that you most want to travel to. Explain why you want to travel there. Write about what kinds of things and places you want to see there.

Research, make and annotate a timeline covering the past thirty years of history. Note down the most important events during this period. Wikipedia is a good place to start with this. Write all your notes in your target language. BONUS: Talk through what you discovered with someone else who speaks your target language.

Think about a topic that excites you. Take the time to outline and plan out a full presentation about that topic. Look up whatever words you need to know, figure out how you will explain the topic in the most coherent fashion. If you have time, perhaps give a trial run of the presentation. BONUS: Deliver the presentation, either to friends or in a more public/formal way at a meetup or language exchange group.

Search for a comedian working in your language on YouTube or any other video sharing site. Watch a video (or several) for the complete time allotted. BONUS: Once the time is finished, try to retell any one of the jokes in your own words.

Make a prediction for how you see the future unfolding. What do you think the world and the society in which you live will look like in twenty years from now? Do you think much will have changed? Describe this imagined future in as much detail as you can in the time allotted.

Write for thirty minutes about what you would like eat if you knew you were going to die the next day. What food would you choose for this final meal? Why would you choose these foods? What do you think you'd be thinking as you ate this last meal? What memories would the food stir up?

Write about how you see the role that religion plays in your society. Do you think it plays a positive role? How does your country compare to other countries (near and far) in this way? Do you think it needs changing? If so, why? If not, why not?

Use a website or an app in your target language to take some trivia quizzes. Do a web search for "[your target language] trivia quiz". There should be several options. If you aren't finding any dedicated quiz sites, look for media outlets or magazines in your target language. Most should have some kind of quiz.

Write what you think about climate change. Do you think it is something that will affect the present generation living on the earth? What are possible solutions to prevent it? What do your friends and family think about climate change?

Do a web search for dishwasher or microwave manuals in your target language. Take the time to read through the manual from the beginning (skipping any pages of legalese language that usually are located at the beginning). Would you be able to operate this machine after reading the manual? BONUS: look at your own electronic appliances and see how many new words you now know.

Read an article in a prominent newspaper or magazine written in your target language. Write a letter to the editor of the newspaper in response. State what you feel the article got right. If anything could have been improved, include suggestions for how they could have covered the topic more clearly. BONUS: Send this off!
Take the time to pick an electronic book to start reading. Find something that interests you. Start reading! Try not to look up too many words in a dictionary.

Research the natural resources / wealth of the country where your target language is spoken. Are there any national parks? Are there major mining operations? Find out as much as you can in the time available. BONUS: Write up a summary of what you learnt, or teach it to someone else.

Read the constitution or any other founding / core documents used by the country where your target language is spoken. Read authentic contextual materials (start with Wikipedia) in your target language to understand why these texts are as they are. BONUS: Translate these documents into the language of your mother-tongue. Compare with any translations that already exist.
Make up a ghost story. Either say this out loud, or write it down. BONUS: record this story and post it on YouTube, Soundcloud or your blog.
Make up a story involving a monster that the hero has to overcome. Either say this out loud, or write it down. BONUS: record this story and post it on YouTube, Soundcloud or your blog.
Make up a story that could be characterised as 'science fiction'. Either say this out loud, or write it down. BONUS: record this story and post it on YouTube, Soundcloud or your blog.

Visit this page (http://bit.ly/wikitranslate) to learn how to register to translate Wikipedia pages. Follow the steps, then open wikipedia in your target language. Pick a page that hasn't been translated into English yet. Spend the rest of the time allocated to translate from your target language to English.

Write for the alloted time about why you're studying this language. Why did you choose this particular language? How do you think you'll benefit from being able to speak / understand it? BONUS: Post this to Lang-8 and/or your blog.
Visit Amara's site (https://amara.org/) and get an account. Once you're registered, click through to the 'Community' section, pick a course provider and get translating / making subtitles!
Visit this site (https://www.ted.com/participate/translate) and register to translate / subtitle TED talks from and into your target language. Spend the rest of the time working on a specific video.

Spend half the time watching a video in your target language, one that has subtitles in English. For the second half of the time period, watch the same clip again, but with subtitles turned off. Compare your understanding. What do you know now that you didn't before?

Write a series of sentences, each one using a different pronoun and verb so that you cover all the verb conjugation possibilities. (For example, I ran to school, you dove in the pool, he wore a shirt and so on). Once you're done with the past tense, do it all again with the present tense. BONUS: Post these sentences to Lang-8.com and get corrections.

column1: Lost in a Foreign City Scenario
column2: Imagine you're lost in a foreign city where no one speaks your native language, and your phone is out of battery. Write or speak out loud (ideally to someone else) a description of how you'd deal with this situation. Describe how you'd feel and which phrases you'll use in target language.

column1: Compare and Contrast Two Books or Films
column2: Choose two books or films that you have read or watched recently in your target language. Write an essay comparing and contrasting the two. Discuss the similarities and differences in plot, characters, and themes.
Write or speak out loud a description of a dream you had recently. Remember to use past tense and try to be as detailed as possible.

column1: Give a Speech in Your Target Language
column2: Choose a topic that you're passionate about and write a speech in your target language. Practice delivering the speech out loud for a full 30 minutes.
Research and learn 10 new idioms in your target language. Write sentences using these idioms correctly, and practice saying them out loud.

column1: Write a Letter to Your Future Self
column2: Write a letter in your target language to yourself, dated five years in the future. Talk about your current life, goals, and what you expect for the future. Include questions to ask yourself in the future.
Choose a controversial topic and write a balanced argument presenting both sides of the issue. Make sure to use appropriate vocabulary and sentence structure.
Imagine you've recently visited a restaurant in a country where your target language is spoken. Write a detailed review of your dining experience, including the food, service, and ambiance.

Research a city or country where your target language is spoken and create a detailed travel itinerary for a week-long trip. Include landmarks, restaurants, and activities, along with descriptions of each place in your target language.
Choose a song with meaningful lyrics in your target language and translate them into your native language. Practice singing the song in your target language.

column1: Teach a New Skill Using Target Language
column2: Make a video or audio recording teaching someone how to do something using only your target language. Examples could include cooking a recipe, playing a game, or tying a specific knot.
Create 30 new vocabulary flashcards in your target language, focusing on words you find difficult to remember or words specific to your interests.

column1: Listen to a Talk Show or Podcast
column2: Find a talk show, radio program, or podcast in your target language that discusses interesting topics. Listen for 30 minutes, and try to summarize the content afterward.
Choose a current event or issue in the country where your target language is spoken. Write an opinion piece expressing your thoughts on the matter, making sure to support your arguments.
With a language partner or on your own, roleplay a difficult situation, such as a disagreement or an emergency, using your target language.

column1: Create a Quiz About Your Target Language
column2: Write a quiz that consists of 10 questions about the grammar, vocabulary, or culture of your target language. Share it with a language-learning buddy or group and discuss the answers together.
Find a meme or joke in your target language and translate it to your native language. Try to retain the humor and explain why it's funny if necessary.

column1: Summarize an Article in Your Target Language
column2: After reading a news article or opinion piece in your target language, write a brief summary of the content in the same language. Practice your writing skills and comprehension.
Research a historical event that occurred in a country where your target language is spoken. Write a summary of the event, ensuring you use the appropriate vocabulary and grammar.
With a fluent speaker, friend, or language-exchange partner, conduct a mock interview in the target language. You can choose any profession or industry for the interview.

column1: Rewrite a Fairytale in Your Target Language
column2: Choose a classic fairy tale and rewrite it in your target language. Try to be as creative as possible and give the story your personal touch.
Write a diary entry describing your day or a notable event that happened recently. Be sure to include your thoughts and feelings in your target language.
Design a trivia game with questions related to the culture, history, or geography of a country or region where your target language is spoken. Play the game with friends or language partners.
Find a traditional recipe from a country where your target language is spoken and translate it into your native language. Try making the dish yourself and see how it turns out.

Write a job advertisement or description for an imaginary position in the country where your target language is spoken. Be sure to include the necessary qualifications, responsibilities, and benefits.

column1: Translate a Scene from a Movie
column2: Choose a scene from a movie or TV show in your target language and translate the dialogue into your native language. Try to convey the tone and meaning of the original dialogue as closely as possible.
Choose a topic with two opposing views and have a self-debate. Present arguments for each side and try to challenge yourself to think critically in your target language.

Come up with a fictional product or service and create a 30-second commercial script in your target language promoting it. Be creative and consider what makes the product unique and how it will benefit customers.

column1: Learn About and Describe an Art Movement
column2: Research an art movement from a country where your target language is spoken. Write a summary of the movement, its prominent artists, and the significance of their work.

column1: Summarize a Podcast or Radio Show
column2: Listen to a podcast or radio show in your target language and try to summarize its content as accurately as possible.

column1: Write a Letter to a Fictional Character
column2: Choose a fictional character from a book or movie in your target language and write a letter to them. You can discuss their story, ask them questions or give advice.

column1: Translate Comic Strips or Graphic Novels
column2: Choose a comic strip or graphic novel in your target language and translate it into your native language. Pay attention to the visual details and the tone of the writing, as well as the characters' personalities.
Watch a film in your target language and write a review discussing its plot, characters, and cinematography. Include your own opinion on whether the film is worth watching.
Think of a unique language learning exercise that you believe would be effective in improving your skills in your target language. Share it with other language learners and gather feedback.
Find 5 tongue twisters in your target language and practice saying them out loud. This will help improve your pronunciation and fluency.
Choose an artwork related to the culture of the country where your target language is spoken. Describe the artwork, its creator, and its significance in your target language.
Write a short autobiography focusing on important events in your life while using your target language. Include emotions and descriptions to make your writing engaging.
Choose a TED Talk about a topic that interests you and translate the speech into your target language. This will challenge your vocabulary, grammar, and listening skills.
Research and learn 10 local proverbs or sayings from the country where your target language is spoken. Write sentences using these proverbs and practice saying them out loud.
Imagine you're on a trip in a country where your target language is spoken. Write a daily journal entry describing your experiences, the places you've visited, and the people you've met.

column1: Play a Board Game in Your Target Language
column2: Choose a board game that can be played in your target language, either a translated version or a game that is specific to the country. Play with friends or fellow language learners for a fun study session.

column1: Act Out a Play or Movie Scene
column2: Choose a scene from a play or movie in your target language, and act it out with a language partner or on your own. Focus on pronunciation, intonation, and emotion in your performance.
Make a meme using an inside joke, cultural reference, or language-specific humor in your target language. Share it with other language learners or native speakers for a good laugh.
